questions.text: If you find a great deal but it costs more than you planned, do you buy it anyway?
options: Maybe if it looks worth it
No, I stick to my budget

questions.text: Do you try to save at least some money each time you get paid, even if it’s small?
Do you often think about what you’ll be doing financially in 5 or 10 years?
When you’re upset, do you shop, eat out, or spend to feel better?
Do you follow a budget (even roughly)?
How comfortable are you borrowing money (credit card, loan) if it helps you now?
Does owning trending or luxury items matter a lot to you?
Would you give money or help someone in need, even if it might make your own financial progress slower?
Do you postpone fun purchases to save for something bigger later?
Do you get anxious when you don’t have a financial buffer/savings?
How often do you check your bank balance or spending in a month?
If an investment is risky but has a big payoff, are you more likely to try it or avoid it?
Do you prefer experiences (travel, concerts) or material things (gadgets, clothes) when spending?
When you receive extra money (birthday, gift, bonus), do you save it, split it, or spend it?
Do you set financial goals (e.g. saving for a car, startup, etc.)?
Do you often buy things on impulse (without planning)?
If you borrow, do you try to pay off early or just minimum?
Is status or appearance (how you look, what people think) important when you spend money?
Do you believe your financial success is more about luck or about habits / discipline?
Do you avoid thinking about financial issues until they become urgent?
options: No, I try to stay proactive

questions.text: How often do you compare your financial situation to that of friends or peers?
Would you rather have a stable job and less stress, or riskier work with big upside?
Do you invest (or want to invest) in skills or education now for future returns?
Do you enjoy researching things before buying (read reviews, compare prices)?
Do you feel satisfied when you save money rather than spend it?
Are you okay with a modest lifestyle if it means financial security?
When planning a trip or vacation, do you budget ahead or just wing it?
Do you see debt as a tool or as a trap?
How often do you spend on things for status or to impress others?
Do you believe giving back (charity, helping friends/family) is as important as building wealth?
If a risky opportunity comes with possible big reward, do you take it now or wait until you’re more prepared?
Do you cut back on small luxuries (coffee, eating out) to reach bigger financial goals?
Do you plan for emergencies (saving for unexpected bills)?
Is your spending controlled by emotions sometimes (boredom, peer pressure, social media)?
Do you feel proud of your financial achievements, even if small?
If you had savings, would you rather invest, lend, or leave it idle?
Do you think about what legacy or impact you want to leave behind (family, society)?
How often do you delay purchase decisions to think about whether you really need something?
Do you believe financial education (books, courses) is important?
Do you share financial tips or learnings with your friends?
When you see others with lots of money, do you feel inspired or envious or indifferent?
Do you check interest rates, fees, etc., before committing to credit or purchases?
Would you rather spend extra for quality vs bargain with risk of lower quality?
Do you keep track of your subscriptions or recurring payments?
When money is saved, do you prefer to watch it grow (invest) or just keep it safe (bank)?
Are you okay with taking small financial risks in daily decisions (starting a side gig, investing)?
Do you believe that generosity/giving is part of financial success?
If you could, would you pay someone to help you manage finances or prefer doing it yourself?
Do you prefer to see your money in visual tools (graphs, charts) or simply 'know roughly' how things are?
At the end of the month, do you feel relief if you saved, worry if you didn’t, or neither?
